name: electricity production, lignite | electricity, high voltage | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/7568/documentation

This dataset represents the production of high voltage electricity in an average lignite power plant in the Ukraine in 2008. This dataset stands for all brown coal, i.e. the sum of sub-bituminous coal and lignite. ;;NoneAll exchanges in this dataset except for emissions of SO2, NOx and particles have been overtaken from the global dataset, which in their turn are production-weighted averages of the figures in the datasets in ecoinvent version two, which are valid for the following 10 countries: AT, BA, CZ, DE, ES, FR, HU, PL, SI, SK. The exception values have been determined using a bottom-up approach. It consists in the collection of information about single plants. ;;The average electrical efficiency has been calculated with data from IEA/OECD statistics and amounts to 27.0% (see parameters).;;The following comments are valid for the structure of the version 2 datasets.; ; - for the assessment of main characteristics (sulphur and ash content of coal, efficiency of the plant) and CO2 a bottom-up approach has been used. It consists in the collection of information about single plants.  ;- The size distribution of particle emissions has been derived from German data.  ;- Halogene emissions have been estimated on the basis of the content of the species in the country-specific coal input mix, assuming average retention rates. ; - For CO and particle emissions average values for the former UCTE are included (Union for the Coordination of the Transmission of Electricity, since 2009 replaced by ENTSO-E European Network of Transmission System Operators for Electricity).  ; - The country specific emissions of N2O depend on the share of DeNOx.  - Emissions of trace elements were calculated by means of a formula (CORINAIR) using the ash content in the country-specific coal input mix and average transfer coefficients for coal power plants, taking into account the share of DeSOx installed. ; - Emission of uranium and thorium radioactive isotopes were assumed proportional to the corresponding element emitted with particles; the other non-gaseous radioactive isotopes of the uranium and thorium decay chain were assumed proportional to the emitted U-238 or Th-232. ; - The emission of gaseous radon and K-40 are taken from the literature.;IEA. 2009. Coal information, 2009 edition. Documentation for beyond 2020 files. International Energy Agency. ;;European Environment Agency (1991) CORINAIR Inventory; VOC"s Default Emission Factors

From the constructed lignite power plant ready to produce electricity. 

From reception of lignite and operating materials at power plant gate.


This activity ends with 1kWh of high voltage electricity produced at the power plant and arrived at the busbar. 

This dataset includes: 
 - all operation and maintenance activities and materials of the power plants. 

 - Particle removal (dedusting of the flue gas)
  - Desulfurisation and denitrification. These processes are described in separate modules; it can be decided by changing the values of NOx and SOx retained whether and how much DeNOx and DeSOx are installed. 
 - Cooling: It is assumed that all plants use wet cooling with a cooling tower. No cooling tower is included in this dataset (will be implemented in future versions)
- Loss of feed water 
 - Losses from gross electricity production, e.g. for internal use


This dataset doesn"t include 
 - raw materials extraction, decommissioning and waste treatment as these activities are already included in the infrastructure datasets
 - transformation of the electricity produced
 - The disposal of non-recycled ashes is modelled separately.
 - Use of fuel oil for startup, as this can be neglected for lignite power plants because these are run for a long time (2-3 years) without being shut down.
category: D:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/35:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/351:Electric power generation, transmission and distribution/3510:Electric power generation, transmission and distribution

processDocumentation.technologyDescription: POWER PLANT:;Lignite power plant input is a dataset which consists of a mix of 30% 100MW power plant and 70% 500MW power plant. The plants are used for basic load with 6000 hours of operation at full capacity per year. The plants are assumed to operate 200000 hours during its lifetime. ;OTHER DATA:;; - Average efficiency: 27.0% (IEA/OECD 2010); - Share of installed capacity with desulfurisation: 20.0% (rough estimation based on sulfur mass balance; - Average efficiency of desulfurisation installations: 92% (rough estimation based on Dones et al. 2007; - Share of installed capacity with denitrification (primary and/or secondary installations): no data; - Average efficiency of denitrification installations: no data; - Share of installed capacity with particle filters: no data; - Average efficiency of particle filters: no data; - IEA 2012. Coal Power Database. International Energy Agency Clean Coal Centre, London ; - IEA/OECD. 2010. Electricity Information 2010. International Energy Agency (IEA), Paris Cedex (FR). Part IV. Detailed OECD Electricity And Heat Data.; - Dones, R., Bauer, C., R\xc3\xb6der, A. (2007) Kohle. In: Dones, R. (Ed.) et al., Sachbilanzen von Energiesystemen: Grundlagen fur den \xc3\xb6kologischen Vergleich von Energiesystemen und den Einbezug von Energiesystemen in \xc3\x96kobilanzen fur die Schweiz. Final report ecoinvent No.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription:
Data from 1993 have been updated for year 2000. No changes were made for the 2008 dataset, but uncertainty was adjusted. 

Most of the exchanges were extrapolated through production-weighted averages of the datasets of the following 10 countries: AT, BA, CZ, DE, ES, FR, HU, PL, SI, SK.

The original data were valid for the burning of 1MJ of lignite. In this dataset, the values are scaled to the net output of 1kWh of electricity, based on the electrical efficiency.

exchanges.description:
Calculated value. Lignite ash has often high content of sulfur (as Ca SO4), high content of free lime, and large variations in composition. It is therefore not suitable for recycling in cement production, 
Lignite ash can be backfilled in opencast lignite mines. In a global weighted average, about 6% of the ash are recycled (Weighted average with electricity production data (Itten&Frischknecht 2012) and ash recycling values of 12 countries (AT, BA, CZ, DE, ES, FR, HU, MK, PL, SI, SK) (RÃ¶der et al. 2007).

Country ash values calculated from mass balance.

Source: 
Itten R. and Frischknecht R. (2012) Life Cycle Inventories of Electricity Mixes and Grid. ESU-services Ltd., Uster, Switzerland.

exchanges.description:
Calculated value. Based on the total particle emissions, global production-weighted average of ecoinvent version 2 countries. 
The shares of the three particulates classes are taken from Dones et al 2007, Tab. 9.39 p. 130 and amount to
-\tparticulates >10um: 5%
-\tparticulates 2.5-10 um: 10%
-\tparticulates < 2.5 um: 85%

Global total emissions without any particulate filter were calculated to amount to 207 g/kWh and were then figured together with the share of installed particle filter and efficiency of the filter (see technology comment for details).

exchanges.description:
Calculated value. At the moment, the lignite power plant input consists out of mix of a 100MWe power plant (30%) and a 500MWe power plant (70%). 
For this calculation, 6000 load hours per year are assumed. It is assumed that a total of 200"000h is reached during the lifetime. A capacity of 500MW is taken for the calculation.

exchanges.description: Calculated value departing from the installed desulfurisation, its efficiency and the SO2 emitted in the air (see Technology Comment for details). According to R\xc3\xb6der et al. 2007, about 20-60% of the sulfur contained in the coal don\"t turn into SO2 but can be found in the ash. A factor of 40% is taken here for calculations.

exchanges.description:
Rough assumption. No data were available in the Power Database, so that the values for Russia were overtaken. These values are calculated values, based on the IEA Clean Coal Centre Coal Power Database
Calculation was made with the content of SO2 in the flue gas (mg SO2/m3) and a flue gas volume factor (m3/GJ burned): 444m3/GJ burned (EEA 2008)

EEA. 2008. Air pollution from electricity-generating large combustion plants. An assessment of the theoretical emission reduction of SO2 and Nox through implementation of BAT as set in the BREFs. European Environment Agency, Copenhagen. EEA Technical report No 4/2008, ISSN 1725-2237, ISBN 978-92-9167-355-1. Tab. B.6 p. 38
